text: I know the answer to this, too, because I've heard you say it, but anyhow, I know the listeners are going to want to know this. At the end of White Gold Wielder, it seems like Covenant's dead. Can you bring him back? Well, you know, I always want to say gone but not forgotten. One of the things that happens in the course of White Gold Wielder is that I work very hard to establish the idea of people who come back from the dead. Now, in the first trilogy, there's a really crucial point which involves the breaking of the law of death. And this is one step along the path. What this means is that somebody in our life with enough power can essentially bring up ghosts to serve them. Or ghosts can affect or communicate with or be present to the living now because the law of death has been broken. But that's not, of course, the same thing as they're being fully present or as they're being as effective as the living or of their being to impose their wills or of their being physically corporately. I mean, there's all kinds of degrees to these things. What happens, among other things, in White Gold Wielder is that another barrier gets broken down. Heil, Troy, Ian, and Leint brings Hallian back from the dead. Now, there are various requirements which have to be present. There is an intact physical body. You know, Sundra kept her body with him. So they have, you know, a body in which she can be reincorporated. And the dead spirit is then refused into the body. And this is crucial because it makes possible Covenant's victory at the end. I mean, Covenant defeats Lord Fowl after he's been killed. Well, you know, this character isn't going to disappear at this point. If he's strong enough to beat Lord Fowl after he's dead, you know he's not gone. Besides, after the whole thing's over, he and he's the one who's having a conversation with Linden and explaining that. Now, this is a subtle point, but it's important. At the end of The Power That Preserves, Covenant has a kind of a little conversation with the creator during the transition back to the real world. Now, it's when Linden goes back to the real world, it's Covenant that she's having a little conversation with. This is not a trivial development. It has, you know, it has a lot of implications for what may happen in the future in these stories in terms of the adjustment of roles which is taking place. But I also did it to remind people again and again that, yes, Covenant's body has been killed. And in terms of the real world, he is dead. But in terms of the land, you know, that spirit lives. His friends were alive when he got to the land. And if there's a future in which Linden Avery goes back to the land, there's no reason why Covenant isn't going to be there. And so the door is open for me to do what I may want to do in the future if I ever decide to do it. What about just a brief statement on the, I don't know, I guess the success of your books? I can't think of maybe except with a possible exception of Tolkien, any other fantasy books that have been as successful as yours. Well, I think that's true that except for Tolkien, there hasn't been another one. Now, you have to keep these things in perspective. By and large, I sell probably ten times as much as the average fantasy book. And by and large, Tolkien sells about ten times as much as I do. You know, so there's still Tolkien in capital letters and then there's me in fine print. But it is true that these books have been more popular than most other fantasy that comes out these days. And it's difficult to explain that in a lot of ways because there are an awful lot of good writers out there writing nowadays who are doing fantasy. I always talk about Patricia McKillop and she's done a trilogy, her Riddle Master series. She's an astonishing writer, does wonderful work, and I will never be able to explain to you why my books are so much more popular than hers. But there are certain kinds of things that I think are clear. And one of them is that I provide the epic fantasy experience that nobody else since Tolkien does. I mean, no matter what my peers are doing in fantasy, they are not doing it on this scale. And the scale puts a lot of pressure on in order to write a convincing 500,000-word novel in which people don't get bored and in which you don't lose track of what's happening and in which the writer doesn't drop stitches and forget characters and in which it all fits together in the end. You know, not everybody can do that. But you can do the same thing on a short story scale. You can do the same thing on a regular novel scale. But when you try to stretch that to 500,000 words, for a lot of people, the fact that you're stretching, it shows. It just doesn't become – it doesn't seem natural. It doesn't – for a lot of other writers. I think my particular talent as a writer is that when you give me a canvas that big, I know exactly what to do with it. You ask me to write a normal-size novel and I really have to struggle because I have – there isn't enough room. And so things get twisted out of shape when I try to make them fit on the picture. And I can have lots of trouble trying to get a short story or a novel into focus. But you give me that much room and I know what to do. So that means that from a reader's point of view, a reader who wants to dive into something 500,000 words long and sort of revel in it for that kind of long reading experience that you don't get from a normal novel but you do get from Tolkien. Well, they can get that from me. It's going to be consistent and coherent and logical and it's all going to fit together and it's going to come out in a way that makes sense. And you can trust that from page one in my books. And that kind of epic reading experience I think is something that a lot of people yearn for. It comes rarely in life and it's one reason Lord of the Rings is so popular and it's one reason why my books are popular. Excellent. Yeah, that's very good. I hadn't thought of that but you're right. Okay, my third one, the last one. I teach a fantasy class at Odessa College. And whenever I can I try to use quotes from authors, you know, for the students' benefit. And do you have any, one thing I keep trying to teach them, tell them, convince them of the value of fantasy. Does it have a value? I mean a student will say, oh, it's an escape literature. Forget about it. You know, it's not the real world. Fantasy is the most fundamental form of literature in my mind. Historically, of course, it is the first form of literature. You know, when you go back to what has existed for two or four thousand years, it's all fantasy. In fact, we didn't have any other kind of literature until much more recent times. And there are reasons for that. It's because it meets a particular need and expresses a particular side of the human personality, which in the old days it was so obvious that that was what stories were for. And what storytelling was for, that it never occurred to anybody to do anything else. Then somehow or another we invented realism and we invented, you know, storytelling, whereas the storytelling becomes a reflection of the actual world instead of a reflection of envisioned worlds. And we've gone so far down that road in Western literature in the past 500 years that we've reached a point where we've forgotten that there used to be – the literature used to do something else. But I think what literature used to do is something that we've lost track of, not because we didn't need it, but because like everything else, we got involved in what we were doing and we drifted away. Anyway, there's something – there is an aspect of being human that doesn't get expressed in realistic prose. The fact is if we're awake 18 hours a day, we spend 17 of those hours in a fantasy world. Now, what I mean is very simple. Our imaginations, whether we're conscious of using them or not, are the fundamental tool with which we cope with the real world. You're sitting here listening to me talk and you're trying to decide what your next question is going to be. That's fantasizing. You figure out, you know, I'm late. People in another room will be doing this and so for which I should have been there five minutes ago. That's fantasizing. When I get home, my wife's going to yell at me, but I'm going to tell her off. That's fantasizing. You know, everything we do, we prepare ourselves for situations, we figure out, we solve problems, we do everything by using our imaginations, by fantasizing. And of course, when we're asleep, we're ruled by fantasy. The fantasy-making impulse on the part of human beings is our fundamental survival trait. And it is one of the key things that makes us human. And yet try to find a literature that deals with that in the realistic mainstream. That is an aspect of who we are that gets lost when you start writing a literature that focuses on reflections of the real world. Now, I wouldn't, you know, I don't claim for a second that those reflections aren't terribly valuable. And it's a good and strong thing that we have realistic literature and whatnot. But it's not the whole story on literature. It's not the whole story on human beings, either as human beings or as readers. When you start writing good fantasy, what you're doing is you're trying to turn the focus of your fiction around from the world back into the human mind. And you're trying to reach down into the things buried in each of our imaginations that we all have in common. You're trying, essentially, good fantasy deals with the imagination itself. And if I had to, you know, come up with a one-word definition of what magic is in the Chronicles of Tom's Covenant, I would say that magic is imagination. imagination. That's what good fantasy novels deal about, from Lord of the Rings to my books to Patricia McKillop to anything else. It deals with the side of being human that dreams and fantasizes and which solves problems, among other things. The difference, of course, in a fantasy is that probably the problems can be solved. Whereas in the real world, although you invent a solution, it turns out not to fit the circumstances, and the circumstances can sometimes overwhelm you anyways. But still, if you weren't inventing those kinds of solutions, if you weren't fantasizing in your real world, you would be dead already. The human race would have died out, you know, half a million years ago. Somebody fantasized using a club to bring down game, and so that little branch of, you know, ape man didn't starve to death. Somebody fantasized taking this smoldering kind of thing and, you know, putting a little more wood on it and building it into a fire and driving back heat and doing something with food and whatnot. And the human race didn't starve to death. I mean, we're bloody physically ill-equipped to cope with the world that animals cope with. We don't have the strength. We don't have the smell. We don't have the claws. We don't have the hide. We don't have the, you know, anything. How did puny little human beings become the dominant species on this planet? Because we've got an imagination. People fantasize possibilities, and those turn out to be what save your life. That's the side of being human that fantasy novels are about, and I don't think of it as escapism at all. I think of it as really looking at yourself in the mirror. Excellent. Okay. Yeah, we're going to have to let you go. That's very fine. I mean, we could talk for hours on this, but that's fine. That's enough. That's probably two weeks' worth of shows. Listen, I would like to send these tapes to you. Can you give me an address? Do you want me to send them to the publisher?

So that means that from a reader's point of view, a reader who wants to dive into something 500,000 words long and sort of revel in it for that kind of long reading experience that you don't get from a normal novel but you do get from Tolkien.

Excellent. Yeah, that's very good.
I hadn't thought of that but you're right.
Okay, my third one, the last one.
